repnme.cdata!:
Community based procurement : value for
            money analysis

abstracts.cdata!:
In the India operations of the World
            Bank, there is little evidence as yet to substantiate that
            community based procurement results in value for money in a
            fair and transparent manner. In order to understand
            community based procurement in relation to value for money
            (VfM), governance and accountability, a study was needed to
            explore these concepts and their dynamics. The present study
            focuses on Community Based Procurement (CBP) outcomes across
            completed sub-projects with a focus on the following key
            questions: 1) value for money - is community based
            procurement more economical for implementation? 2)
            Sustainability - is there evidence of better operation and
            maintenance of items and services created through CBP? 3)
            Participation - what is the extent of community
            participation in CBP? 4) Enabling factors - what are the
            facilitating processes and environmental factors that
            positively influence the outcomes in CBP? The study on CBP
            was carried out in 84 successful subprojects from three
            community driven development (CDD) projects in India (in the
            states of Andhra Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh and Tamil Nadu) and
            local government units (Gram Panchayats1) in the state of
            Kerala, to explore linkages both in terms of enablers and
            outcomes. This field study was undertaken in 2009.

Community based procurement : value for

repnme.cdata!:
India - Madhya Pradesh District Poverty
            Initiatives Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Madhya Pradesh District
            Poverty Initiatives Project for India were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: instead of operating stand-alone projects,
            it is better to make them as part and parcel of mainstream
            schemes so that the government can avail of all available
            resources. The role of private sector in playing an active
            role as a partner in Bank projects on livelihood and poverty
            alleviation needs to be looked into for future projects. All
            manual and guidelines should be prepared at the beginning of
            the project itself and not after the project has started.
            Capacity building should be given very high priority.
            Implementation of sub projects should start only after
            sufficient capacity building is achieved. Any attempt to
            fast track without proper foundation can result in
            manipulation and diluting project objectives. Enhancing the
            capacity and skills of project coordinators to manage
            projects through relevant training and exchange programs is
            important for effective project implementation. It will be
            important to provide them opportunities for platform for
            sharing and cross-learning from the experience of other
            projects in the country.

repnme.cdata!: India - Madhya Pradesh Poverty Initiatives Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Madhya Pradesh District Poverty
            Initiatives Project, aims at improving opportunities for the
            poor, and vulnerable groups, particularly women, in meeting
            their own social, and economic development activities,
            through the creation of income security opportunities for
            the rural poor, empowering disadvantaged groups through the
            promotion of village organizations. The project components
            follow. 1) Community investments will finance demand-driven
            sub-projects, proposed by the Common Interest Groups (CIGs),
            to be approved by the village development committees, and
            discussed by district sub-committees. Based on social
            assessments, it is expected that CIG subprojects will fall
            into three categories: a) skills and organizations, such as
            micro-enterprises; b) infrastructure, such as roads and
            housing; and, c) livelihood security, such as
            micro-irrigation. Village funds, established through
            community cash contributions would finance operation, and
            maintenance costs, and, Innovation Funds, would finance
            demonstration projects, proposed by non-governmental
            organizations. 2) Institutional, and human capacity building
            will develop self-reliant, and self managed community based
            organizations, focused on project administration, human
            resource development, communications, organization
            strengthening, and, monitoring and learning.

692953.trustfund:
TF038525-INDIA:  MADHYA PRADESH DISTRICT
            POVERTY INITIATIVES,TF021582-DISTRICT POVERTY INITIATIVES
            PROJECT (DPIP),TF039274-INDIA - MADHYA PRADESH DISTRICT
            POVERTY INITIATIVE PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
India - Madhya Pradesh District Poverty
            Initiative Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Madhya Pradesh District Poverty
            Initiative Project, will address the linkages between
            environmental degradation, and poverty, to help prevent the
            environmental degradation, resulting from the cumulative
            effect of the small District Poverty Initiatives Programme
            (DPIP) investments, possibly from either individual,
            negligible impacts, or harmful subprojects. This
            environmental assessment examines adversity on human health,
            and the stocks of natural resources resulting from the
            subprojects' implementation. Environmental screening
            checklists have been developed as a baseline to mitigate
            environmental effects, through a three step process:
            location of the project, classification of subprojects, and
            environmental analysis, which determines the specific
            actions to be required. Besides the application of standard
            environmental regulations, mitigation measures specify that:
            1) new embankments to control flood, and soil erosion should
            be in place; 2) construction of new multipurpose village
            ponds should be avoided, to prevent surface water
            contamination, as well as any changes in drainage patterns,
            to control the spread of diseases to the population, or
            adversity to aquatic habitat; 3) tubewells will be properly
            cased to avoid groundwater contamination; 4) waste disposal
            sites will be established, and, 5) compost pits will be
            constructed to attain sanitation standards, and avoid health risks.

display_title.display_title:
India - Madhya Pradesh District
            Poverty Initiative Project : environmental assessment : Main report
